Comment: >Inviting immigrants means having to accept cultural differences and potential influences on their own. Living on an Island for so many generations have made the people deeply rooted in customs. Thus its hard for even Christianity to penetrate.  This is a nationalist myth, though. It was never true. Japan has always been deeply connected to its neighbors. Buddhism came to Japan from Korea. Its government structures were based first on China, then  Germany and the current one was literally created by Americans. No matter how hard it tried, Japan was never able to unseat Christianity once it got a foothold. Japan uses a Chinese writing system. There have been 100,000s Korean and Taiwanese people in Japan since the 19th century, and Japan itself has multiple indigenous minorities (the Ainu people,  Ryukyuans) and an "untouchable caste" (Burakumin"). The idea of a culturally homogenous Japan was just never really true.
